URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/op-passport-design-document/8275

Summary:
<classification>announcement</classification>

<about>
The thread announces the OP Passport project, funded by the OP Season 5 Builder Grant, aimed at enhancing privacy, security, and active participation in Optimism governance.
</about>

<overview>
- OP Passport: Open-source platform for governance participants using Zero-Knowledge Proof (ZKP) technology.
- Features: Digital identity passports, badge issuance, public and anonymous attestations, user dashboard.
- System Framework: Front-end web interface, back-end services, smart contracts, database.
- Governance Roles: Delegates, delegators, badgeholders.
- Badge Criteria: Voting power, participation rate, endorsements, seasonal contributions.
- Visual Designs: UI/UX design and attestation flow.
- Attestation Mechanisms: Peer-to-peer message attestation, anonymous attestation using ZKP.
- Smart Account Wallet: Safe (CORE) implementation for managing on-chain identity passports.
</overview>

<reaction>
- Questions about differentiation from existing dashboard features.
- Clarifications on the project's focus, reputation building, and privacy-preserving governance.
- Inquiries about user incentives and badge parameters.
- Offers for user testing and collaboration on related projects.
</reaction>

<tldr>
The thread announces the OP Passport project, which aims to enhance privacy, security, and active participation in Optimism governance using Zero-Knowledge Proof technology. It includes features like digital identity passports, badge issuance, and anonymous attestations. The community provided feedback and asked for clarifications on various aspects of the project.
</tldr>

Summary:
<classification>discussion</classification>

<about>
The discussion revolves around a potential contradiction between Optimism's goal of reducing transaction fees and the value of OP tokens, which is derived from governance over transaction fee revenue.
</about>

<first_post>
- OP holders benefit from increased transaction fee revenue
- This seems contradictory to Optimism’s mission of reducing transaction fees
- Questions if this misalignment could be problematic and suggests aligning governance interests better
</first_post>

<reaction>
- Some believe there is no issue, citing the importance of incentives in decentralization
- Others argue that fees are paid in ETH, not OP, and that OP's value is purely from governance utility
- A point is made that Optimism must remain competitive with other L2s and L1s, implying that lower fees are essential for user retention
- Suggestions include making OP holders benefit from increased ecosystem activity and offering users the option to pay fees in OP
</reaction>

<tldr>
This is an old thread and the information may be outdated. The discussion addresses a potential conflict between Optimism's goal of reducing transaction fees and the value of OP tokens, which is tied to transaction fee revenue. Opinions vary, with some seeing no issue and others suggesting ways to align governance interests better.

Summary:
<classification>feedback</classification>

<about>
The thread is about gathering community feedback on an experimental impact metric-based voting system for Retroactive Public Goods Funding (Retro Funding) in the Optimism ecosystem.
</about>

<overview>
- Introduction of impact metric-based voting to simplify and standardize the evaluation process.
- Prototype of a metric-based voting interface called "Impact Calculator" developed by Buidl Guidl.
- Request for community input on the prototype, focusing on evaluating onchain deployments and open source libraries.
- Key features of the Impact Calculator: selecting impact vectors, ballot view, detailed view, and configuration options.
- Links to relevant resources and prototypes: [Impact Calculator](https://impact-calculator.vercel.app/), [OS Observer](https://www.opensource.observer/).
</overview>

<reaction>
- General agreement that the new system could simplify the voting process and provide clearer criteria.
- Concerns about evaluating non-technical projects and regional communities.
- Suggestions for improving the UI/UX of the prototype, including better graph readability and tooltips.
- Skepticism about the potential for gaming the metrics and the need for combining on-chain and off-chain metrics.
- Emphasis on the importance of qualitative metrics and human judgment in evaluating impact.
</reaction>

<tldr>
The thread discusses an experimental impact metric-based voting system for Retro Funding in the Optimism ecosystem, seeking community feedback on a prototype called "Impact Calculator." The community generally supports the idea but raises concerns about evaluating non-technical projects, potential metric gaming, and the need for qualitative metrics and human judgment.
</tldr>

- Commission's mandate: prevent capture of the Token House by any one stakeholder or group
- Delegated 10M OP from the Governance Fund through Season 6
- Goals: provide alerts on power imbalances, vote on proposals subject to Citizens’ House veto, advocate for decentralization, and transparency
- Commission structure: high impact delegates, simple majority voting

- Commission Lead: organize meetings, coordinate votes, author reports, serve as tie breaker

<overview>
- **OP Rewards Deep Dives**: Detailed analyses of the impact of OP incentives on various protocols like Polynomial, Synthetix, Celer, Via, Pika, Hop, and Lyra.
  - [Polynomial Protocol](https://gov.optimism.io/t/incentive-impact-analysis-polynomial/6796): Incentives led to a 23x surge in trading volume but had limited long-term impact.
  - [Synthetix](https://gov.optimism.io/t/incentive-impact-analysis-synthetix/6841): Unique ecosystem-level incentive program; notable success with Kwenta.
  - [Celer](https://gov.optimism.io/t/op-rewards-impact-analysis-celer-protocol/6795): Effective early-stage liquidity rewards; unallocated funding impacts expansion.
  - [Via Protocol](https://gov.optimism.io/t/analysis-report-via-protocol-phase-1-grant-proposal/6844): Detailed grant allocation and execution analysis.
  - [Pika Protocol](https://gov.optimism.io/t/op-rewards-impact-analysis-pika-protocol/6746): Positive impact on TVL and trading volume; decline post-airdrop snapshot.
  - [Hop Protocol](https://gov.optimism.io/t/op-incentive-program-impact-analysis-for-hop-protocol/6741): 10% of OP tokens claimed; projected to sustain for 3-4 years.
  - [Lyra](https://gov.optimism.io/t/analysis-of-op-rewards-changes-impact-on-lyra-protocol/6740): Spike in new traders due to trading rewards; effect not enduring.
- **OP Mainnet Bi-Weekly Update**: Regular updates and analytics insights.
  - [August Issue 1](https://gov.optimism.io/t/bi-weekly-op-mainnet-onchain-analysis-first-half-of-august/6683)
  - [August Issue 2](https://gov.optimism.io/t/bi-weekly-op-mainnet-onchain-analysis-second-half-of-august/6769)
- **Data Infrastructure**: Enhancements in data abstraction and mapping on Dune.
  - [OP Mainnet Wallet Address Summary](https://github.com/duneanalytics/spellbook/pull/4127): Summary data abstraction for wallet addresses.
  - [Contract Deployer Mapping](https://github.com/duneanalytics/spellbook/pull/4322): Enhanced mapping for smart contracts.
  - [Add DEX - Lifi Optimism](https://github.com/duneanalytics/spellbook/pull/4082/): Added new DEX Lifi to OP Mainnet DEX data abstraction.
- [Start contributing to Optimism Collective analytics](https://app.dework.xyz/optimism-community/main-space-35638/view/board-l8x6w840)
</overview>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/retro-funding-5-expert-voting-experiment/8613

Summary:
<classification>announcement</classification>

<about>
The thread announces the Retro Funding 5 experiment, which aims to test if experts make better OP allocation decisions on OP Stack contributions compared to non-experts.
</about>

<overview>
- Retro Funding 5 will reward contributions to the OP Stack.
- Research questions focus on differences in voting between experts and non-experts, and the impact of smaller evaluation groups.
- Expertise is measured via a score based on past GitHub activity, using an algorithm developed by Karma3Labs and Open Source Observer.
- Voter groups include high expertise badgeholders, non-expert badgeholders, and expert guest voters.
- Random sampling ensures equal probability of selection for all citizens.
- Treatment and control groups will be used to validate hypotheses.
- Voting process involves subgroups voting on specific project categories.
- Further details on voting design and conflict of interest policies will follow.
</overview>

<reaction>
- Excitement about the experimentation and the potential for useful data from the review process.
- Questions about the random sampling approach and the interaction between experts and non-experts.
- Inquiries about support for research on voting mechanisms and practical details on participant notification and involvement.
</reaction>

<tldr>
The thread announces Retro Funding 5, focusing on testing expert versus non-expert voting on OP Stack contributions. It details the research questions, expertise measurement, voter groups, and voting process. Reactions include excitement, questions about random sampling, and inquiries about participant notification and involvement.
</tldr>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/op-incentive-program-impact-analysis-for-hop-protocol/6741

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
The thread provides an in-depth analysis of the OP (Optimism Pairs) incentive program's impact on the Hop Protocol, focusing on metrics such as bridge and user counts, retention, volume bridging, and grant sustainability.
</about>

<overview>
- Increase in bridge and user counts after OP rewards initiation
- Positive retention trends, especially on Eth and Polygon
- Decrease in average bridge volume due to smaller amounts being bridged
- Operation Quest on Hop had limited impact on new user adoption
- 10% of the 1 million OP tokens claimed within a year, suggesting grant sustainability for 3-4 years
- Recommendations: rebalance rewards to prioritize GnosisChain, increase fee discounts to 90%
- Full analysis available on [Dune Analytics](https://dune.com/impossiblefinance/op-rewards-hop-protocol-deep-dive-analysis)
- Detailed report on [Google Docs](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Kd-xPgxr8rs-MT8tRViSYXrrHGvSEudnflqao3Vm6Aw/edit?usp=sharing)
</overview>

</tldr>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/season-4-grants-council-renewal-process/6887

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
The thread provides detailed information about the renewal process for the Grants Council for Season 4 in the Optimism Governance Forum.
</about>

<overview>
- Grants Council introduced in the Reflection Period before Season 3
- Council Lead appointed by the Foundation; 8 Council Reviewers elected by Token House
- Renewal process involves Special Voting Cycles #12a and #12b
- Intent Budget Proposal required for Intent #2, specifying baseline funding and potential retroactive rewards
- Community members can propose their own Intent Budget Proposals
- Token House votes to approve one Council Intent Budget Proposal, effectively electing the Council Lead
- If approved, Reviewers are elected in Special Voting Cycle #12b
- Elected Council members receive an Attestation
- Renewal process part of the Intent Budgeting process, potentially continuing beyond Season 4
</overview>

<tldr>
The thread outlines the renewal process for the Grants Council for Season 4, detailing the steps for submitting and approving Intent Budget Proposals, electing the Council Lead and Reviewers, and the overall structure of the renewal process.
</tldr>

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/collective-grant-policies/5833

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
This thread provides detailed information on the Collective Grant Policies for Governance Fund grants and OP Chain grant programs within the Optimism ecosystem. It outlines the rules and guidelines for grant recipients to follow.
</about>

<overview>
- Policies apply to all Governance Fund grants and OP Chain grant programs, excluding Retroactive Public Goods Funding (Retro Funding) grants.
- Disclosure requirements for grants-as-a-service arrangements.
- No Sale Policy for OP User Incentives: OP received should not be sold by the grant recipient or related persons.
- Lock-Up Policy: OP received through other grants should not be sold for one year.
- Definition of "Effective Sale" includes various forms of selling or transferring economic consequences of OP tokens.
- Self-Delegation of Grants: User incentive grants cannot be self-delegated for governance; locked grants can be self-delegated after one year.
- Changes to Proposals: Any changes to the use of grants must be approved through a new proposal.
- Critical Milestones and Clawback: Non-completion of milestones can result in clawback of remaining tokens.
- Grants to Other OP Chains: Must follow Collective Grant Policies and not target users from other OP Chains.
- Enforcement: Violations can result in grant clawback or refusal to deliver milestone-based portions.
- Change Process: Policies can only be updated during Reflection Periods or extraordinary circumstances.
- [Grant Misuse Reports category](https://gov.optimism.io/t/about-the-grant-misuse-reports-category/7578)
- [Grant Token Lock Explainer](https://gov.optimism.io/t/grant-token-lock-explainer/5060)
- [Grant Misuse Reporting Process](https://gov.optimism.io/t/grant-misuse-reporting-process/7346)
- [Reporting form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeLySdMNyQ8aJdzOrMN3BfMy8fChsDuSQW6LLuIRuVm9gmavQ/viewform?usp=sf_link)
- Updated information includes clarifications on effective sales, enforcement by the Foundation, and the exemption of RetroPGF grants.
</overview>

<tldr>
This thread provides comprehensive guidelines for the Collective Grant Policies within the Optimism ecosystem, detailing rules on grant usage, disclosure, no-sale policies, lock-up periods, and enforcement mechanisms. It includes updates and clarifications on various aspects of the policies.
</tldr>

- Governs activities of Experiments, Builders, and Milestones and Metrics Sub-Committees
- Cycle Procedure: Submission Period, Review Period, Decision Period

- Milestone Hub: Space for grant finalists to report milestone progress
- Reviewer Metrics Accountability: Ensure effective communication and accountability of reviewers
- Official Record and Rule Changes: Maintain tracker of proposals, review effectiveness of procedures, amend procedures as needed
- Rules of Decision: Voting procedures for Sub-Committee members and Council-wide votes
</overview>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/mission-request-microgrants-for-experimental-projects/8514

Summary:
<classification>announcement</classification>

<about>
The thread is about a mission request for microgrants aimed at supporting experimental projects on the Optimism Mainnet.
</about>

<overview>
- Mission request for experimental development of user applications, developer tools, games, art, and DeFi primitives.
- Total grant amount: 50k OP, with a maximum of 2,500 OP per grant.
- Applicants are encouraged to request 80% of the impact they believe they will generate, with the rest potentially rewarded retroactively.
- Mission aims to support newer and more experimental projects that may not be competitive under larger grant requests.
- Grantees must launch their projects within 6 months and ensure they are usable end-to-end.
- Success metrics include milestones, project deployment, usability, user reach, and contribution to developer growth.
- North Star Metric: Number of active addresses interacting with grantee’s contracts.
</overview>

<reaction>
- Addition of a North Star Metric to enable data-driven decisions and standardized evaluation of Season 6 missions.
</reaction>

<tldr>
The thread announces a mission request for microgrants to support experimental projects on the Optimism Mainnet, with a total grant amount of 50k OP. The mission aims to foster new and innovative projects, with success measured by milestones, deployment, usability, and user engagement. A North Star Metric has been added to standardize evaluation.
</tldr>

- **Work Units**:
  - **Education**: Partnerships with universities, courses on Ethereum, over 100 graduates.
  - **Community**: Network building with various Latin American Ethereum communities.

  - **Kipu Impact**: Quadratic Funding rounds, public goods funding analysis.

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/grants-council-charter-season-6/8170

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
The thread provides detailed information about the Grants Council Charter for Season 6 of the Optimism governance framework.
</about>

<overview>
- Goals: streamline grant process, empower delegates, reduce non-Council delegate workload
- Council Structure: Lead and 15 Reviewers across four teams (Superchain, Optimism Mission, Audit and Special Mission, Milestones and Metrics)
- Responsibilities: review grant applications, publish reports, ensure transparency, assess milestones
- Election Terms: members elected each season, additional reviewers can be added if needed
- Accountability: subject to removal, re-election, and transparency requirements
- Budget: proposed by Lead, includes variable rewards based on performance
- Additional Details: operational details determined by Council Lead, KYC managed by Foundation
- Iteration: updates to the Charter published on GitHub
</overview>

<tldr>
The thread outlines the Grants Council Charter for Season 6, detailing goals, structure, responsibilities, election terms, accountability, budget, and additional operational details. The Charter aims to streamline the grant process and ensure transparency and effective governance.
</tldr>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/upgrade-proposal-9-fjord-network-upgrade/8236

Summary:
<about>
The discussion revolves around Protocol Upgrade #9, also known as the Fjord Network Upgrade, for the Optimism Collective. The proposal includes several technical improvements aimed at reducing gas costs, enhancing data compression, and improving the robustness of L1 data pricing. The proposal was approved by the Token House and was subject to a veto vote by the Citizens' House, which ultimately decided not to veto it. The voting period is closed, and the proposal is set to be enacted.
</about>

<overview>
- EIP-7212 precompile for secp256r1 curve support
- Brotli batch compression for 5-15% lower data availability costs
- Improved L1 data pricing robustness
- Increased max-sequencer-drift parameter to 1800 seconds
- Various parameter changes and updates to L2 contracts
</overview>

<reaction>
- General support and excitement for the upgrade
- Some users requested more detailed technical documentation and test results
- Concerns about the lack of external audit, though internal reviews were conducted
- Positive feedback on the potential cost savings and efficiency improvements
- Queries about the rationale behind specific changes, such as the increased sequencer drift
</reaction>

<tldr>
The Fjord Network Upgrade proposal for the Optimism Collective includes several technical improvements aimed at reducing costs and enhancing efficiency. The proposal was approved by the Token House and not vetoed by the Citizens' House, and it is set to be enacted. The community generally supports the upgrade, with some requests for more detailed technical documentation.
</tldr>

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/incentive-impact-analysis-kwenta/6867

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
The thread provides an in-depth analysis of the impact of OP incentives on the Kwenta protocol, including proposed and actual distributions, key takeaways, and recommendations for future incentive programs.
</about>

<overview>
- Kwenta is a derivatives trading platform funded by the Optimism Governance Fund.
- Initial proposed distribution: Platform Migration Incentives (600K OP), Competition Prizes (130K OP), DAO Contributors (170K OP).
- Actual distribution: Trading Rewards (600K OP), Trading Competitions (120K OP), DAO Contributors (180K OP).
- Key takeaways: Need for a process to adjust distribution methods, lump sum distribution model is gameable.
- Recommendations: Develop a process for distribution alterations, implement prerequisites for incentive applications, less predictable rewards schedules, granular analysis for sustained usage.
- Impact: Increased daily transactions and transacting addresses, significant trading volume on Tuesdays due to reward epoch ending.
- Resources: Links to various analyses, proposals, and reports related to Kwenta and other protocols.
</overview>

<tldr>
The thread provides a detailed analysis of the impact of OP incentives on Kwenta, highlighting the need for a process to adjust distribution methods, the gameability of lump sum distributions, and recommendations for future incentive programs. The analysis shows increased daily transactions and trading volume, especially on Tuesdays due to reward epoch endings.
</tldr>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/analysis-of-op-rewards-changes-impact-on-lyra-protocol/6740

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
This thread provides an analysis of the impact of OP (Optimism) rewards changes on the Lyra protocol, focusing on user behavior, trading volume, and platform engagement.
</about>

<overview>
- Trading rewards led to a spike in new traders in mid-April and May 2023, but the trend was not sustained.
- Average weekly trading volume remained consistent post-rewards implementation.
- Optimism regained market share from Arbitrum in trading volume distribution.
- OP quests had minimal impact on overall platform trends and user engagement.
- Initial positive effects on retention metrics were observed, but long-term impact was limited.
- Suggested strategies for Lyra include targeted marketing campaigns and dynamic reward structures.
- [Full analysis on Dune](https://dune.com/ahkek/op-rewards-lyra-protocol-deep-dive-analysis)
- [Detailed document](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1UbbLhHKcXkrxemERM6wOLWpM69L6dA-2rxbDzi0CYu4/edit)
</overview>

<tldr>
The analysis indicates that while OP rewards initially attracted new traders and improved retention, the long-term impact on trading volume and user engagement was limited. Optimism's rewards had a more lasting effect compared to Arbitrum. Suggested strategies for Lyra include targeted marketing and dynamic reward structures.
</tldr>

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/retropgf-impact-profit-framework/7034

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
The thread provides detailed information on the Retroactive Public Goods Funding (RetroPGF) framework, focusing on the principle of "impact = profit" and how it is applied within the Optimism Collective.
</about>

<overview>
- RetroPGF allocates rewards based on past contributions that have positively impacted the Optimism Collective.
- The principle "impact = profit" ensures contributors are rewarded proportionally to their positive impact.
- Impact is defined as the value created for the Collective, while profit is the value extracted from it.
- The framework includes specific categories for evaluating impact: OP Stack, Collective Governance, Developer Ecosystem, and End User Experience & Adoption.
- Profit is not limited to monetary gains but includes various forms of value extraction.
- Venture funding is not considered profit within this framework.
- Emphasis on transparency and accurate reporting of profit by projects.
</overview>

<tldr>
The thread provides an in-depth explanation of the Retroactive Public Goods Funding (RetroPGF) framework, emphasizing the principle of "impact = profit" and detailing how impact and profit are defined and measured within the Optimism Collective.
</tldr>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/op-rewards-impact-analysis-pika-protocol/6746

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
This thread provides an impact analysis of the $OP rewards on Pika Protocol, detailing the effects on various metrics such as total value locked (TVL), trading volume, fee revenue, number of trades, and number of active traders.
</about>

<overview>
- Pika Protocol received 900,000 $OP tokens in August 2022 to boost user growth and adoption.
- Tokens were allocated to traders, liquidity providers, and grants.
- Key metrics analyzed: TVL, trading volume, fee revenue, number of trades, and number of active traders.
- TVL increased from $1m to $9m within a month, peaking at $15m in June 2023, but dropped to $5m in July 2023.
- Trading volume peaked at $165m in January 2023 but dropped significantly after the Optimism #2 airdrop snapshot.
- Fee revenue followed a similar trend to trading volume, peaking at $128k in January 2023.
- Number of trades and active traders peaked in January 2023 but dropped sharply after the airdrop snapshot.
- The analysis suggests that while the $OP incentives had a positive impact, many users were primarily motivated by the airdrop.
- [Dune analytics dashboard](https://dune.com/kit_kwan/pika-protocol-op-rewards-deep-dive-analysis)
- [Full report](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1wCM_4mxWY8KGMa0fsNSS4ukF35RV4kWs/view)
</overview>

<tldr>
The $OP rewards had a significant positive impact on Pika Protocol's metrics, including TVL and trading volume, but many users were primarily motivated by the airdrop, leading to a sharp decline in activity post-snapshot.
</tldr>

<overview>
- Framework aims to guide OP Labs teams on obtaining external security reviews.
- Emphasizes that security starts with developers, not just external audits.
- Recommends audits for code where safety is of existential importance.
- Divides projects into two categories: infrastructural code (less audit needed) and smart contract code (more audit needed).
- Preparation steps include enumerating system invariants, creating security documentation, and assessing test coverage.

- [Trail of Bits report](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/blob/develop/docs/security-reviews/2022_11-Invariant_Testing-TrailOfBits.pdf) for test coverage assessment.
</overview>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/developer-advisory-board-internal-operating-procedures/7343

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
The thread provides detailed internal operating procedures for the Developer Advisory Board (DAB) within the Optimism governance framework. It aims to ensure transparency in decision-making processes related to Delegate Mission Requests, Mission Applications, and technical milestone assessments.
</about>

<overview>
- DAB assesses technical aspects of Delegate Mission Requests, Mission Applications, and milestone completion.
- DAB meetings occur every 3 weeks; agendas and minutes are published.
- Delegate Mission Request Assessment Procedure:
  - Review and approve/deny DMRs under Intent #1.
  - Publish final approvals with justifications by the end of the assessment period.
  - Public communication on forum posts; internal votes must be publicly justified.
- Mission Application Assessment Procedure:
  - Review and provide feedback on applications.
  - Three-week review period for each voting cycle.
  - Objectives: Review, Applicant Feedback, Grants Council Advising.
  - Detailed review criteria for technical feasibility, proposed solutions, and execution plans.
- Milestone Assessment Procedure:
  - Review work-product to determine milestone completion.
  - At least 3 members must evaluate if milestones are met before disbursement.
- Final communications include summaries of DAB work and recommendations, posted on the forum.
</overview>

<tldr>
The thread outlines the internal operating procedures for the Developer Advisory Board (DAB) in the Optimism governance framework, detailing processes for assessing Delegate Mission Requests, Mission Applications, and technical milestones to ensure transparency and effective decision-making.
</tldr>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/beyond-kpis-rewarding-passion-and-unmeasurable-impact-in-decentralized-ecosystems/5948

Summary:
<classification>discussion</classification>

<about>
The discussion is about the limitations of using Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) in decentralized ecosystems and the importance of recognizing and rewarding unmeasurable contributions that align with the core values and ethos of these projects.
</about>

<first_post>
- Decentralized ecosystems thrive on decentralization, transparency, and democratization.
- Overemphasis on KPIs can hinder organic growth and lead to short-term thinking.
- KPIs may not align with core values, leading to a loss of passion and innovation.
- Importance of recognizing and rewarding unmeasurable impact to maintain project integrity.
- Advocates for a holistic approach that values both measurable and unmeasurable contributions.
</first_post>

<tldr>
The thread discusses the pitfalls of over-relying on KPIs in decentralized ecosystems and emphasizes the need to reward unmeasurable contributions that uphold the core values and ethos of these projects for long-term success and sustainability.
</tldr>

Summary:
<classification>discussion</classification>

<about>
The discussion revolves around incentivizing governance participants in DAOs with retroactive rewards for making beneficial voting decisions.
</about>

<first_post>
- Low participation in DAO governance votes
- Current incentives (e.g., POAPs) increase participation but not decision quality
- Proposal to reward voters retroactively based on the positive outcomes of their decisions
- Challenges in evaluating the outcomes of proposals
- Suggestion to use a separate body for evaluation or self-set evaluation metrics by proposal writers
</first_post>

<reaction>
- Concerns about defining "went well" and "went badly" outcomes
- Potential for peer pressure and gaming the system
- Suggestions to hide vote results until finality to reduce peer pressure
- Ideas to reward correct voting only after a threshold of correct votes
- Discussion on the difficulty of evaluating complex proposals
- Mention of other DAOs' incentive mechanisms, like Gitcoin and MakerDAO
- General agreement on the need for incentivizing governance but skepticism about the proposed method
</reaction>

<tldr>
The thread discusses incentivizing DAO governance participants with retroactive rewards for beneficial voting decisions. While the idea is generally supported, concerns about defining successful outcomes and potential gaming of the system are raised. Suggestions include hiding vote results and rewarding correct votes after a threshold.
</tldr>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/incentive-impact-analysis-polynomial/6796

Summary:
<classification>discussion</classification>

<about>
The discussion revolves around the impact and effectiveness of incentive programs, specifically focusing on Polynomial's trading incentives within the Optimism ecosystem.
</about>

<first_post>
- Incentives drive short-term usage spikes; tapering and vesting recommended for sustainability
- Retroactive airdrop for Polynomial Vault V1 depositors lacked longevity
- Incentives led to a 23x surge in trading volume but slower user growth
- Polynomial’s XP system innovatively structured incentives but wash trading remains an issue
</first_post>

<reaction>
- Reward > fees leads to wash trading; reward < fees is less exciting but more resistant to sybil/wash trading
- Polynomial Trading Season aimed to build a community and attract new traders
- Vesting periods suggested to delay incentives and show long-term commitment
- Importance of tracking long-term customer value to assess incentive effectiveness
- General agreement on the need for further analysis and optimization of incentive programs
</reaction>

<tldr>
The thread discusses the impact of Polynomial's trading incentives on the Optimism ecosystem, highlighting short-term usage spikes, issues with wash trading, and the need for sustainable incentive structures. Participants suggest tapering, vesting periods, and tracking long-term customer value to improve future programs.
</tldr>

</about>

<overview>

- **Protocol Upgrade #8: Stage 1 Decentralization**: Increases Security Council threshold, transfers Guardian role, and changes L2 ProxyAdmin ownership.
- **Governor Update Proposal #2**: Improves advanced delegation allowance calculations.
- **Season 6 Grants Council Operating Budget**: Proposes a budget of 610,000 OP for efficient grant distribution.
- **Code of Conduct Council Operating Budget for Season 6**: Proposes a budget of 55,000 OP to enforce community standards.
- **Developer Advisory Board Operating Budget**: Proposes a budget of 90,000 OP to support technical guidance and grant evaluations.
- **Season 6 Intents Ratification**: Focuses on decentralization, expanding the Superchain, and growing the developer community.
- All proposals mentioned have passed.

The thread discusses the role of venture capital (VC) funding in Retroactive Public Goods Funding (RetroPGF) within the Optimism ecosystem. It explores whether VC funding should be considered when evaluating the impact and profit of projects.
</about>

<first_post>
- Introduces the debate on VC funding's relevance in RetroPGF
- Highlights key discussion points from various perspectives
- Provides the Optimism Foundation’s perspective on the issue
</first_post>

<reaction>
- Some believe VC funding should be disclosed and considered in impact evaluation
- Others argue VC funding is irrelevant and should not influence RetroPGF decisions
- Opinions vary on whether RetroPGF should prioritize projects in need of funding
- Discussion on whether resources used to create impact should be considered
- General consensus that VC-funded projects can create public goods
- Emphasis on rewarding impact rather than the need for funding
</reaction>

<tldr>
The thread discusses the role of VC funding in RetroPGF, with varying opinions on whether it should be considered in impact evaluations. The Optimism Foundation maintains that VC funding is irrelevant to the impact=profit framework but will require disclosure in future rounds. The debate highlights differing views on prioritizing projects in need and considering resources used to create impact.
</tldr>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/draft-proposal-moving-to-a-grants-council/3945

Summary:
<classification>feedback</classification>

<about>
The thread discusses a draft proposal for transitioning to a Grants Council in Optimism's governance structure. The proposal aims to address challenges in the current grants process and improve efficiency and accountability.
</about>

<overview>
- Proposal to replace multiple committees with a single Grants Council
- Grants Council to consist of 1 Lead and 8 Reviewers with full decision-making authority
- Non-Council delegates to elect Council members and oversee the Council
- Council members subject to checks, including adherence to a Delegate Code of Conduct
- Two sub-committees: Builders Sub-Committee and Growth Experiments Sub-Committee
- Council responsibilities include filtering grant applications, approving grants, and ensuring transparency
- Council members to be compensated, with specific roles and responsibilities outlined
- Budget for the Council set at 5M OP for Season 3
- Updates based on feedback: removal of 1-year lock-up on rewards, added transparency measures, and clarified responsibilities
- Final version of the proposal posted [here](https://gov.optimism.io/t/special-voting-cycle-9a-grants-council/4198/2)
</overview>

<reaction>
- Concerns about the 1-year lock-up period for grants and compensation
- Suggestions for improving transparency and accountability
- Mixed opinions on the requirement for Council members to hold >0.5% voting power
- Support for the proposal's direction but calls for more clarity on certain processes
</reaction>

<tldr>
The thread discusses a draft proposal to transition to a Grants Council for managing Optimism's grants process, aiming to improve efficiency and accountability. Feedback led to updates, including removing the 1-year lock-up on rewards and adding transparency measures. The final proposal is available [here](https://gov.optimism.io/t/special-voting-cycle-9a-grants-council/4198/2).
</tldr>

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/opml-optimistic-machine-learning-on-blockchain-an-efficient-on-chain-ai-approach/6577

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
The thread introduces OPML (Optimistic Machine Learning), an efficient on-chain AI approach using an optimistic approach for AI model inference on the blockchain.
</about>

<overview>
- OPML enables AI model inference on blockchain using a fraud-proof mechanism.
- Low-cost, high-efficiency ML service compared to ZKML; can run large models on common PCs without GPU.
- Uses a verification game to ensure decentralized and verifiable consensus on ML service.
- Single-phase verification game involves off-chain execution and on-chain arbitration using a lightweight DNN library.
- Multi-phase verification game improves performance by leveraging GPU/TPU acceleration and parallel processing.
- Ensures consistency and determinism in ML results using fixed-point arithmetic and software-based floating-point libraries.
- Comparison between OPML and ZKML highlights OPML's advantages in model size, cost, and training support.
- OPML is still under development and open-sourced on [GitHub](https://github.com/OPML-Labs/opml).
</overview>

<tldr>
OPML (Optimistic Machine Learning) is an efficient on-chain AI approach using a fraud-proof mechanism for AI model inference on the blockchain. It offers low-cost, high-efficiency ML services and ensures decentralized consensus through a verification game. OPML is still under development and open-sourced on GitHub.
</tldr>

- [Grant Misuse Report Template](https://gov.optimism.io/t/grant-misuse-reporting-process/7346#grant-misuse-report-template-16) provided for structured reporting.
- Updates and clarifications on the process, including the publication of the [Grant Misuse Report Database](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1-KPQiubxH93EUtrXtSWOmc4208j5j97kfE-HmzQumsI/edit#gid=0).
</overview>

<tldr>
The thread outlines the Grant Misuse Reporting Process in the Optimism ecosystem, detailing how to report misuse, the criteria for valid reports, and the steps involved in the process. It includes definitions, scope, protections for involved parties, and a structured template for reporting.
</tldr>

<classification>discussion</classification>

<about>
The discussion is about exploring various economic mechanisms to fund public goods in favelas in Brazil through community-led initiatives and crowdfunding.
</about>

<first_post>
- Proposal to test economic mechanisms by disbursing funding in Brazilian favelas
- Aim to shift public goods funding from government to community-led crowdfunding
- Process suggested by economist Robin Hanson:
  - Crowdsource ideas for funding mechanisms
  - Use prediction markets to select top mechanisms
  - Fund initiatives and evaluate effectiveness
  - Repeat with variations and different projects
- Potential funding mechanisms include traditional contracts, AI selection, quadratic funding, prizes, venture capital, freelance platforms, and auctions
- Possible focus on physical or digital infrastructure projects
- Connections with various individuals and groups for funding, projects, community engagement, research, media, and location
- Personal motivation and dedication to the initiative
</first_post>

<tldr>
The thread discusses a proposal to test various economic mechanisms for funding public goods in Brazilian favelas through community-led crowdfunding. The process involves crowdsourcing ideas, using prediction markets, and evaluating effectiveness. Potential mechanisms include traditional contracts, AI selection, quadratic funding, and more. The poster seeks collaboration to lead this initiative.

- Emphasizes user protection, decentralization, and economic autonomy.
- Describes the document as a living entity that will evolve with protocol innovations.
- Specifies the roles and expectations of Users, Chain Governors, and Chain Servicers.
- Details user protections, including state transition validity, security, uptime, and universal upgrades.
- Outlines Chain Governor and Chain Servicer protections focused on economic autonomy and technical configurability.
- Highlights the importance of the Platform as a public good and the need for sustainability, security, and survival.
- Stresses that user protections take precedence over other participant protections.
- States that enforcement will be through Optimism Governance resolutions.
- Provides interpretive principles for the Law of Chains, including governance minimization, forking, anti-plutocracy, and impact = profit.

</about>

- Goals: attest projects and voters, fund projects, pool funds, distribute funds based on events, easy data querying

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/governance-update-7/6464

Summary:
<classification>announcement</classification>

<about>
Governance Update #7 provides a summary of Voting Cycle #13, the first cycle of Season 4, and outlines plans for future improvements in the Optimism governance process.
</about>

<overview>
- Voting Cycle #13 concluded with significant participation and feedback.
- 27 out of 31 Mission proposals were approved, with 115 grant applications received.
- Key successes: scaling non-core teams, effective approval process, and focused spending.
- Key learnings: need to improve timing, approval/filtering process, voter context, and system accessibility.
- Proposed changes: separate Council and Mission processes, opt-in approval process for delegates, and improve system accessibility.
- Important clarifications on grant policies, required disclosures, multiple submissions, and delegate rewards.
- [Season 4 Feedback Thread](https://gov.optimism.io/t/season-4-feedback-thread/6303/6)
- [23rd OP Community Call Recap](https://gov.optimism.io/t/recording-recap-23rd-op-community-call-was-thursday-july-6th-2023/6204)
- [Guide to Season 3](https://gov.optimism.io/t/guide-to-season-3-course-correcting/3942)
- [Retroactive Delegate Rewards Season 3](https://gov.optimism.io/t/retroactive-delegate-rewards-season-3/5871)
</overview>

<tldr>
Governance Update #7 reviews the outcomes of Voting Cycle #13, highlights successes and areas for improvement, and proposes changes for future cycles. Important clarifications on grant policies and delegate rewards are also provided.
</tldr>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/law-of-chains-v0-1-section-by-section-overview/6515

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
This thread provides an overview of the "Law of Chains v0.1," a framework intended to inform governance decisions within the Optimism ecosystem.
</about>

<overview>
- **Introduction**: Neutrality framework promoting user protection, decentralization, and economic autonomy; living document; socially enforced.
- **Sec. 1 – Covered Participants**: Users, Chain Governors, Chain Servicers; roles may overlap.
- **Sec. 2 – The Platform**: Covers the fundamental protocol for OP Chains and future Superchain.
- **Sec. 3 – User Protections**: Assurances similar to Ethereum; uniform across OP Chains; voluntary user migrations.
- **Sec. 4 – Chain Governor Protections**: Economic choices and technical configurations; economic rewards for legitimate conduct.
- **Sec. 5 – Chain Servicer Protections**: Participatory expectations; respond to transaction margin changes.
- **Sec. 6 – Platform as Commons**: Public good; sustainability, security, and survival; thorough consideration of decisions.
- **Sec. 7 – Users First**: User Protections prioritized over Chain Governors or Servicers.
- **Sec. 8 – Enforcement**: Enforced through Optimism Governance resolutions; protocol upgrades for compliance.
- **Sec. 9 – Interpretation**: Governance minimization; long-term applicability; guiding principles.
- **Sec. 10 – Always**: Stay Optimistic.
- [Full draft link](https://gov.optimism.io/t/law-of-chains-v0-1-full-draft/6514)
</overview>

<tldr>
This thread provides an overview of the "Law of Chains v0.1," a framework for informing governance decisions within the Optimism ecosystem, covering user protections, economic autonomy, and platform sustainability. For more details, refer to the [full draft](https://gov.optimism.io/t/law-of-chains-v0-1-full-draft/6514).
</tldr>

<overview>
- Canyon is the first network upgrade after Bedrock, including the Shapella upgrade from Ethereum.
- Changes include reducing basefee volatility, minor bug fixes, and maintaining EVM equivalence.
- Node operators need to upgrade their nodes to stay in sync.
- The upgrade will activate on multiple mainnets on January 11, 2024.
- Technical specifications include EIPs like EIP-3651, EIP-3855, EIP-3860, EIP-4895, and EIP-6049.
- Security considerations were reviewed internally by OP Labs.
- Impact summary indicates no expected downtime and highlights the importance of Shapella for Ethereum compatibility.
- Action plan outlines the upgrade schedule and steps for node operators.
</overview>

<reaction>
- Multiple delegates with sufficient voting power support moving the proposal to a vote.
- Some users express excitement about the upgrade and its benefits.
- Questions about including additional chains like Lyra Chain were addressed, confirming no need for additional governance processes.
- Some users suggest future upgrades should consider formal audit processes.
</reaction>

<tldr>
The Canyon Network Upgrade proposal for the Optimism ecosystem includes significant changes like the Shapella upgrade, basefee volatility reduction, and bug fixes. It is scheduled to activate on January 11, 2024, with broad support from delegates and no expected downtime. Future upgrades may consider formal audits.

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/incentive-impact-analysis-synthetix/6841

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
This thread provides an in-depth analysis of the impact of Optimism's incentive funding on the Synthetix protocol, including the distribution and usage of OP tokens, the effects on the Optimism ecosystem, and recommendations for future incentive programs.
</about>

<overview>
- Synthetix received 9 million OP in Phase 0 to incentivize liquidity migration and activity on Optimism.
- Initial distribution plan: 2M OP for grants, 3M OP for sUSD liquidity and bridging, 4M OP for SNX/sUSD pool.
- Adjustments proposed in SIP 234 and SIP 242; SIP 234 rejected, SIP 242 approved with modifications.
- Trading rewards program: 5.2M OP distributed over 17 weeks, criticized for promoting wash trading.
- Additional rewards distributed to Curve, Velodrome, Hop, and Lyra.
- Impact on Optimism: minimal increase in daily transactions and network fees, significant trading volume increase.
- Competitive analysis: Synthetix vs. GMX, Synthetix saw higher trading volume but fewer daily traders.
- Recommendations: clarity on grant distribution, incentivizing composable protocols, conservative collaborative funding.
</overview>

<tldr>
This thread provides a detailed analysis of the impact of Optimism's incentive funding on Synthetix, highlighting the distribution and usage of OP tokens, the effects on the Optimism ecosystem, and recommendations for future incentive programs. Key points include the initial and adjusted distribution plans, the trading rewards program, and the competitive impact compared to GMX. Recommendations emphasize the need for clarity and conservative funding approaches.

- Lists of candidates for various council positions provided.

- Security review conducted; no audit deemed necessary
- Proposed Mainnet activation on Feb 22, 2024

</reaction>

<tldr>
The Delta Network Upgrade proposal, aimed at significantly reducing L1 costs through Span Batches, was approved by the Token House but vetoed by the Citizens' House. The proposal received general support but raised concerns about security reviews and node readiness. The Mainnet activation is proposed for Feb 22, 2024.

</about>

<overview>
- QuantumFair is in BETA phase; smart contracts are complete, and integrations are nearly done.
- The protocol allows communities to create on-chain raffles using ERC-721 and/or ERC-20 tokens.
- Raffle parameters include ticket price, ticket asset, raffle objective, reserve price, and expiry date.
- Winners are chosen using API3’s Quantum Random Number Generator (QRNG).
- Funds and prizes are trustlessly transferred to winners and pre-determined beneficiaries.
</overview>

- Positive feedback from a user offering design services for POAPs.
</reaction>

The protocol uses on-chain raffles with various parameters and API3’s QRNG for winner selection. Positive feedback includes an offer for design services.
</tldr>

<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
This thread provides detailed instructions and templates for the Anticapture Commission Reports, which are used to address imbalances or conflicts in the Token House that need to be considered by the Citizens’ House.
</about>

<overview>
- Commission Reports are shared with the Citizens’ House to address imbalances or conflicts in the Token House.
- Two types of reports: Statement of Concern and Request for Veto.
- Reports must be posted on the forum and Discord, tagging badgeholders.
- Requests for veto must be posted before the voting period starts.
- Badgeholders should abstain from voting if further deliberation is needed.
- The Foundation will facilitate deliberation between Houses if necessary.
- Templates provided for both Statement of Concern and Request for Veto.
</overview>

<tldr>
This thread provides instructions and templates for the Anticapture Commission Reports, detailing how to address imbalances or conflicts in the Token House by involving the Citizens’ House.
</tldr>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/final-protocol-upgrade-8-guardian-security-council-threshold-and-l2-proxyadmin-ownership-changes-for-stage-1-decentralization/8157

Summary:
<about>
The discussion revolves around Protocol Upgrade #8, which aims to enhance the security and decentralization of the Optimism Superchain. The proposal was approved by the Token House and was subject to a veto vote by the Citizens' House. The veto period has ended, and the proposal was not vetoed.
</about>

<overview>
- Increase Security Council Safe’s signing threshold from 4 to 10 out of 13 owners
- Transfer Guardian role from the Foundation to a new Guardian Safe controlled by the Security Council
- Appoint the Foundation as Deputy Guardian, with revocable authority by the Security Council
- Reassign ownership of the L2ProxyAdmin contract from the Foundation to the Security Council
- Implement LivenessModule and LivenessGuard contracts to ensure keyholder activity
</overview>

<reaction>
- General support for increased security and decentralization
- Concerns about the high threshold (10/13) potentially causing operational issues
- Agreement on the importance of decentralizing the Guardian role
- Mixed opinions on the 14-week liveness check period; some find it too long
- Some users prefer individual proposals for each change rather than a combined one
</reaction>

<tldr>
Protocol Upgrade #8 aims to enhance the security and decentralization of the Optimism Superchain by increasing the Security Council's signing threshold, transferring the Guardian role, and implementing new security modules. The proposal was approved without a veto, despite some concerns about the high threshold and liveness check period.
</tldr>

<classification>discussion</classification>

<about>
The discussion is about including liquidity providers (LPs) in the governance process of the Optimism $OP token. The thread explores the potential benefits and challenges of granting voting power to LPs.
</about>

<first_post>
- Proposal to include LPs in governance
- Current system only recognizes $OP token holders
- Benefits: increased participation, meeting voting quorum, incentivizing LPs
- Cons: need to upgrade snapshot mechanism
</first_post>

<reaction>
- General agreement on including LPs in governance
- Concerns about forcing a distinction between governance and liquidity
- LPs provide significant utility and have vested interests
- Suggestions for implementation, including whitelisting governance pools and delegating voting power to DEXes
- Challenges in trustlessly whitelisting all LPs, especially with Uni V3 positions
</reaction>

<tldr>
The thread discusses the proposal to include liquidity providers in the Optimism $OP token governance process, highlighting the benefits of increased participation and the challenges of implementation. There is general agreement on the proposal, with various suggestions and concerns about execution.
</tldr>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/voting-cycle-roundup-17/7474

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
This thread provides detailed information about the 17th voting cycle for Optimism governance, including key dates, voting procedures, and proposals up for vote.
</about>

<overview>
- Cycle 17 runs from January 4th to January 24th, 2024.
- Citizens’ House has a one-week veto period following the Token House Voting Period.
- Delegate voting weights snapshot taken when votes go live.
- Voting starts on January 18th at 19:00 GMT on [vote.optimism.io](https://vote.optimism.io/).
- Citizens’ House vetos occur via [Snapshot](https://snapshot.org/#/citizenshouse.eth).
- Proposals moving to a vote in Cycle #17:
  - [Upgrade Proposal #3: Delta](https://gov.optimism.io/t/ready-to-vote-upgrade-proposal-3-delta-network-upgrade/7310)
  - [Proposal to Reclassify Grant Misusage Enforcement](https://gov.optimism.io/t/proposal-to-reclassify-grant-misusage-enforcement/7384)
  - [Code of Conduct Council Enforcement Actions Cycle #17](https://gov.optimism.io/t/code-of-conduct-council-communication-thread/7453)
- Token House Code of Conduct Council decisions are subject to optimistic approval unless vetoed by 12% of votable supply.
</overview>

<tldr>
This thread provides information about the 17th voting cycle for Optimism governance, including key dates, voting procedures, and proposals up for vote. Voting starts on January 18th, 2024.
</tldr>

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
This thread provides detailed information about the results and analysis of the third round of Retroactive Public Goods Funding (RetroPGF 3) by Optimism. It includes insights into the results calculation process, analysis of voting data, verification of results, and grant delivery.
</about>

<overview>
- Results of RetroPGF 3 were published on January 11th.
- Voting results are private to protect badgeholders' choices.
- Results calculation involves verifying signatures and applying a voting algorithm.
- Independent implementations of the results calculator by Agora and OP Labs.
- Anonymized voting data published for analysis.
- Existing analyses by community members on different voting algorithms and data characteristics.
- EZKL received a grant to create ZK proofs for verifying the correctness of results.
- Grant delivery has started, with tokens streamed over 90 days post-KYC approval.
- Recipients must complete the process by January 2025 or forfeit their tokens.
- [Results publication](https://optimism.mirror.xyz/37Bgum6MfTJWDuE41CH9RXSH5KBm_RCL5zsSFeRZl4E)
- [Agora’s implementation](https://github.com/voteagora/rpgf_calculator/tree/main)
- [OP Labs implementation](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-analytics/tree/main/rpgf/rpgf3)
- [Anonymized voting data](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-analytics/blob/main/rpgf/rpgf3/results/anonymized_project_votes.csv)
- [Superfluid progress](https://app.superfluid.finance/vesting?view=0x41BF11E307426c750B84A160891d09A2751CbAA5)
- [Dune dashboard](https://dune.com/0xkhmer/retropgf-3)
</overview>

<tldr>
This thread provides comprehensive information on the results and analysis of RetroPGF 3, including the calculation process, anonymized voting data, verification through ZK proofs, and the grant delivery process.
</tldr>

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/token-house-missions/5881

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
The thread provides detailed information about the Token House Missions for Season 4 of the Optimism governance framework. It explains the new structure, processes, and guidelines for proposing and executing missions aligned with the community's Collective Intents.
</about>

<overview>
- Season 4 focuses on aligning community efforts with Collective Intents.
- Traditional working groups are replaced by Token House Missions for specific initiatives.
- Missions are tightly scoped and must be completed within the season.
- Two types of missions: Proposed Missions (submitted under an Intent) and Foundation Missions (pre-specified by the Foundation).
- Missions are executed by Alliances, which are temporary groups of contributors.
- Alliances can submit up to three Mission proposals per period.
- Detailed steps for applying to accept Foundation Missions and proposing own Missions.
- Proposed Missions are ranked and approved based on Intent Budgets.
- Mission grants are awarded in OP governance tokens, locked for one year.
- Pilot initiatives to increase access to upfront capital, including co-granting contracts and small cash grants.
- Delegates will vote on Proposed Missions during Voting Cycle #13.
</overview>

<tldr>
The thread provides comprehensive information about the Token House Missions for Season 4 of Optimism governance, detailing the new structure, types of missions, execution by Alliances, and processes for proposing and approving missions. It also introduces pilot initiatives for upfront capital access.
</tldr>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/collective-representative-structure-framework/5884

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
The thread provides detailed information about the Collective Representative Structure Framework within the Optimism Governance Forum. It outlines the roles, responsibilities, and procedures for various representative structures.
</about>

<overview>
- Framework includes Boards, Councils, and Commissions
- Representatives manage resources or make decisions for tokenholders or Citizens
- Initial members may be appointed by the Foundation, with future members elected
- Leads are non-voting members focused on procedure and operations
- Structures authorized for a pilot period, then renewed by governance
- Persistent structures require support as they mature
- Dissolution Proposals can be submitted if structures fail their mandate
- Representatives can be removed for failing responsibilities; replacements appointed by Leads or majority vote
- Representatives should only serve in one elected position per Season
- Updated policies for Lead resignation and procedures if membership falls below a threshold
- [Operating Manual](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/OPerating-manual/blob/main/manual.md)
</overview>

<tldr>
The thread outlines the Collective Representative Structure Framework for the Optimism Governance Forum, detailing the roles, responsibilities, and procedures for Boards, Councils, and Commissions, including appointment, election, and removal processes.
</tldr>

- Some users expressed a desire for more detailed plans on future product deployments on Optimism
</reaction>

<tldr>

<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
The thread provides detailed information on implementing a threshold encryption-based front-running protection mechanism for the OP Stack and Bedrock codebase, leveraging the Shutter Network.
</about>

<overview>
- Introduction to Shutterized Optimism: aims to reduce front-running and MEV-related exploits using threshold encryption.
- Requirements and Technical Architecture: outlines the necessary components and their roles, including the Optimism rollup node, sequencer node, keyper set, and frontend library.
- Functional and Non-functional Requirements: details the specific requirements for each component and provisional estimates for non-functional requirements.
- Technical Architecture: describes the keyper set, sequencer, system contracts, and client library, along with the necessary code modifications.
- User Interaction: explains the user experience for submitting encrypted transactions and tracking their status.
- Potential Issues and Solutions: addresses possible failures, latency concerns, and side-channel attacks, along with proposed solutions.
- Future Considerations: discusses potential future improvements, such as using zero-knowledge proofs and involving the keyper committee in preventing reorg attacks.
- Conclusion: summarizes the benefits and feasibility of the proposed architecture.
- [Link to the full document](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1nsAnDZ6jv5AU413IvVp5tNgdtNewpHtJ)
</overview>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/retropgf-3-application-review-process/6916

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
The thread provides detailed information about the application review process for RetroPGF Round 3, including guidelines, participation instructions, and rules for application submissions.
</about>

<overview>
- RetroPGF Round 3 allows anyone to submit an application.
- Over 300 applications submitted in the first two weeks.
- Review process to filter out applications violating rules.
- Reporting mechanism for users to flag rule-violating applications.
- Badgeholder Reviewers assess reported applications.
- 5 Reviewers per application; 3 out of 5 votes needed to exclude.
- Appeals process for wrongfully excluded applications.
- Badgeholder Reviewers cannot vote on their primary projects.
- Future rounds to have an elected Code of Conduct Council for reviews.
- Participation details: form submission by October 16th, review period from October 24th to November 1st, 20k OP rewards for Reviewers.
- Lead Reviewer role with additional responsibilities and rewards.
- Application rules include no promises of future impact, no false statements, no hateful content, no fraud, no advertising, no bribery, no contacting badgeholders privately, KYC requirements, relevance to Optimism, no spam, and no duplicate applications.
- Adjustments made based on badgeholder feedback: self-selection of applications by Reviewers, non-voting Lead Reviewer.
</overview>

<tldr>
The thread provides comprehensive information on the RetroPGF Round 3 application review process, including guidelines, participation instructions, and rules. Badgeholder Reviewers will assess applications, and a reporting mechanism is in place to flag rule violations. Adjustments have been made based on feedback to ensure a fair and efficient review process.
</tldr>

<about>
This thread provides information on how to create a proposal for the Governance Fund Phase 1 in the Optimism ecosystem.
</about>

<overview>
- Governance Fund aims to distribute 5.4% of the initial token supply to projects and communities.
- Any project on Optimism can submit a proposal to request OP tokens.
- Proposals must include a plan to incentivize growth on Optimism.
- Steps to apply:
  - Draft a proposal.
  - Share it on Discord for community feedback.
  - Post the proposal on the forum for delegate feedback.
  - Update the proposal status to [READY] for voting.
  - If passed, the Optimism Foundation will distribute the funding.
- Relevant links: [Grants Council landing page](https://foul-porch-0eb.notion.site/Optimism-Grants-Council-090bb648d1854136b9630c608da7a8bc), [Allocations section](https://community.optimism.io/docs/governance/allocations.html), [Governance docs](https://community.optimism.io/docs/governance/), [Operating Manual](https://gov.optimism.io/t/operating-manual-of-the-optimism-collective-v0-1/592), [Grant Proposal Template](https://gov.optimism.io/t/grant-proposal-template/3233/15)

- Legal and practical considerations, including the need for a small pilot and potential legal risks.
- Interest from various users in participating in the pilot and providing further feedback.
</reaction>

<tldr>

The proposal aims to provide income flexibility and market signals by allowing supporters to donate OP tokens and receive future RetroPGF. The community expressed excitement, concerns about unpredictability and financialization, and suggested leveraging existing tools. Next steps include incorporating feedback, conducting more interviews, and identifying funding sources for a pilot.

- Inquiry about preference between official and third-party bridges
- Official bridge supports any token but takes 7 days
- Third-party bridges are faster but limited to some tokens
- Request for reviews and experiences
</first_post>

<reaction>
- Preference for faster third-party bridges due to the high risk of waiting a week in the crypto world
- Specific third-party bridges mentioned: Orbit Bridge, Binance Exchange, Hop Exchange, Synapse, Stargate
- Some users agree that a week is too risky
- One user mentions the upcoming launch of Bridging as a Service by Elk
- Another user highlights the security advantage of the official bridge
</reaction>

<tldr>
The thread discusses the pros and cons of using the official bridge versus third-party bridges for withdrawing funds in the Optimism ecosystem. Users generally prefer faster third-party bridges due to the high risk of waiting a week, although the official bridge is noted for its security.

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/season-4-alliance-guide/5873

Summary:
<classification>guide</classification>

<about>
This thread provides a guide for forming and managing Alliances for Season 4 in the Optimism governance forum. It outlines the necessary components and best practices for creating effective Alliances to complete Missions.
</about>

<overview>
- Alliances: Groups working together to complete a Mission, can be pre-existing or newly formed.
- Key features: Leader with a Trust Tier, a Mission (Foundation Mission or Proposed Mission), and defensible value.
- Good Alliance traits: Reward distribution plan, conflict resolution plan, and dedicated communication space.
- Additional suggestions: Defined roles for each member, clear distribution of responsibilities, and a platform for forming Alliances (e.g., Discord channel).
- Clarification: All members should actively participate in the Mission; delegates can vouch for proposals but not replace active participation.
- Workshop: An Alliance Forming and Mission Proposal workshop was held on May 30th, 2023, with a dedicated Discord channel created for Alliances.
- Approval process: 4 delegate approvals from delegates with >0.25% votable supply required to move a proposal to a vote.
</overview>

<tldr>
This thread provides a comprehensive guide for forming and managing Alliances in Season 4 of the Optimism governance forum, detailing necessary components, best practices, and additional suggestions for effective collaboration. A workshop and dedicated Discord channel were also established to facilitate Alliance formation.
</tldr>

- Grants Council will be a persistent entity in Season 5 unless dissolved by a proposal.
- Prospective Council Leads must propose a budget by October 11th, 19:00 GMT.
- The budget proposal with the highest proportion of "Yes" votes will be approved.
- Template includes sections for Council Lead details, budget breakdown, and Council Charter links.
- Council will process all Delegate Mission Applications and no longer run its own Request For Grant program.
- Voting Cycles will be 3 weeks long, with the option for the Grants Council to process grants in 6-week cycles.
- Delegates will vote on the Grants Council Operating Budgets and elect Reviewers in Special Voting Cycles.
</overview>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/ratification-of-profit-definition-for-round-4/8312

Summary:
<about>
The discussion revolves around the ratification of a profit definition for Round 4 of Optimism’s Retroactive Public Goods Funding (Retro Funding). The proposal aimed to standardize how past transfers, such as grants and funding, are deducted from the impact assessment to determine the final OP award. The proposal was not ratified, and the fallback definition focusing solely on impact will be used instead.
</about>

<overview>
- Standardized profit definition: Impact - Past transfers = Award in OP
- Categories for past transfers: Optimism grants, VC funding, grants from other ecosystems, revenue
- Specific deduction weights proposed for different types of Optimism grants
- Deliberative process used to determine the profit definition
- Fallback definition: Impact = Award in OP
</overview>

<reaction>
- Mixed opinions on the proposed deductions; some support, others oppose
- Concerns about disincentivizing projects that received grants
- Arguments for and against including various types of funding in the deductions
- Suggestions to refine the process and improve coordination between grant programs and Retro Funding
- General agreement on the need for more context and better-defined metrics
</reaction>

<tldr>
The proposal to standardize the profit definition for Round 4 of Optimism’s Retro Funding was not ratified, leading to the fallback definition focusing solely on impact. The community had mixed reactions, with concerns about disincentivizing grant-receiving projects and suggestions for refining the process and metrics.

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/bedrock-downtime-what-to-know/5792

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
This thread provides important information about the upcoming Bedrock upgrade for the Optimism ecosystem, focusing on the expected downtime and its implications for various stakeholders.
</about>

<overview>
- Bedrock release introduces a modular architecture for the OP Stack.
- Upgrade allows easy conversion of Ethereum execution client to Optimism execution client.
- Up to 4-hour downtime expected; ETH on Optimism remains safe.
- Deposits, withdrawals, and transactions will be paused during the upgrade.
- Node operators need to update their clients for new infrastructure.
- DApp and wallet developers should note that transactions will be paused but data will be preserved.
- Users should avoid transactions during downtime and consider closing positions and removing staked tokens.
- MEV transactions may pose higher risks post-upgrade.
- [Bedrock Explainer](https://community.optimism.io/docs/developers/bedrock/)
- [OP Stack](https://stack.optimism.io/)
- [Upgrade Guide](https://community.optimism.io/docs/developers/bedrock/upgrade-guide/)
- [Node Operator Guide](https://community.optimism.io/docs/developers/bedrock/node-operator-guide/)
</overview>

<tldr>
The Bedrock upgrade for Optimism will involve a 4-hour downtime, during which transactions will be paused. Stakeholders should prepare accordingly, and node operators need to update their clients. ETH on Optimism remains safe.
</tldr>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/introducing-the-collective-feedback-commission/7863

Summary:
<classification>announcement</classification>

<about>
The thread announces the introduction of the Collective Feedback Commission (CFC) by the Optimism Foundation, which aims to involve the community more in the governance design process.
</about>

<overview>
- The Optimism Foundation is transitioning from Phase 0 (community informed design) to Phase 1 (community consulted design).
- The CFC will consist of 10 highly engaged Citizens and 15 high-context delegates.
- Members will provide feedback on early design drafts and will be compensated with OP tokens.
- The CFC will operate for an initial trial period of 6 months starting April 1st, 2024.
- Feedback from the CFC will be shared with the Foundation and may eventually be made public.
- The Foundation will use the feedback as input but is not obligated to incorporate it.
- The CFC is part of a gradual transition to open metagovernance.
</overview>

<reaction>
- Questions about the opt-in process and operational details were raised and addressed.
- Positive reception and support for the initiative.
- Clarifications sought on commitments, roadmap for new participants, and handling of vacancies.
- Suggestions for transparency and reporting on feedback provided by CFC members.
</reaction>

<tldr>
The Optimism Foundation announced the Collective Feedback Commission to involve the community more in governance design. The CFC will consist of selected Citizens and delegates providing feedback on early drafts, with a trial period starting April 1st, 2024. The initiative received positive reactions and raised questions about its operation and transparency.

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/mission-roundup/6206

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
This thread provides information about the requirements and process for mission proposals to be eligible for voting in Optimism's governance system.
</about>

<overview>
- Mission proposals need 4 delegate approvals from delegates with >0.25% of votable supply by June 28th, 2023, 19:00 to move to a vote.
- Approvals indicate readiness for a vote, not endorsements.
- Proposals are ranked under each Intent until the budget is depleted.
- Incorporate delegate feedback and notify them of changes to avoid withdrawal of approval.
- List of proposals ready for vote and those needing approvals provided.
- [Operating Manual](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/OPerating-manual/blob/main/manual.md)
- [How to Vote on Missions: Approval Ranking Example](https://gov.optimism.io/t/how-to-vote-on-missions-approval-ranking-example/6203)
- [Votable supply by delegate](https://dune.com/optimismfnd/optimism-op-token-house)
- Clarifications and updates provided in the comments.
</overview>

<tldr>
This thread provides detailed information on the requirements and process for mission proposals to be eligible for voting in Optimism's governance system, including delegate approval requirements, proposal ranking, and a list of proposals ready for vote.
</tldr>

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
The thread provides an update on the DeVouch project, which aims to create a decentralized vouching system using attestations on the Optimism platform.
</about>

<overview>
- DeVouch allows attestation holders to vouch for projects they trust.
- The project addresses the problem of identifying trustworthy projects among many applying for funding.
- It proposes a solution by maintaining an open layer of attestation data for easy project endorsement visibility.
- Attestations can be made by anyone, and are organized by "Attester Groups" based on the issuing authority.
- The project is in the design phase, with back-end services and API integrations in progress.
- The front-end development will start soon, featuring main views for landing page, project details, and user attestations.
</overview>

Summary:
<classification>informative</classification>

<about>
The thread provides detailed information about the establishment and role of Optimism's Security Council, aimed at advancing the decentralization of the Optimism Superchain Network.
</about>

<overview>
- Introduction to the Security Council and its purpose
- Responsibilities: upgrading L1 protocol contracts, modifying role designations
- Decentralization impact: ensuring no single party can upgrade the system or censor transactions
- Governance impact: procedural steps requiring a vote for the Security Council's initiation
- Phase 0: Security Council as a signer on a 2/2 multisig for OP Mainnet protocol upgrades
- Phase 1: Transition to a single multisig controlled by the Security Council, with a 14-day delay on protocol upgrades
- Related proposals for Token House votes: change to security model, membership ratification, full security model implementation
- [Security Council Charter](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/OPerating-manual/blob/main/Security%20Council%20Charter%20v0.1.md)
- [Collective Council Framework](https://gov.optimism.io/t/council-framework-and-renewal/5884)
</overview>

<tldr>
The thread details the establishment of Optimism's Security Council, its role in decentralizing the network, and the procedural steps requiring Token House votes for its initiation. Key phases include adding the Council as a signer on a multisig and transitioning to full control by the Council.
</tldr>

URL: https://gov.optimism.io/t/retro-funding-4-impact-metrics-a-collective-experiment/8226

Summary:
<classification>announcement</classification>

<about>
The thread is about the announcement of Retro Funding 4 (RF4) by the Optimism Governance Forum, focusing on a new metrics-based evaluation approach for funding public goods.
</about>

<overview>
- RF4 shifts from voting on individual projects to selecting and weighting impact metrics.
- Initial survey findings: balanced interest in quantitative and qualitative metrics, preference for innovation and open source, concerns about gaming metrics, and focus on sustained engagement.
- Workshop insights: metrics grouped into network growth, network quality, user growth, and user quality.
- Post-workshop survey: refined metrics based on feedback, including trusted user model and new metrics.
- Next steps: testing metrics through a simulated voting interface, collecting final feedback, and deciding on the final set of metrics.
- [Details on upcoming retro rounds](https://gov.optimism.io/t/upcoming-retro-rounds-and-their-design/7861)
- [Workshop space on Figma](https://www.figma.com/file/IISdYrF76LrfTZNn4wURUq/%F0%9F%A7%AA-RF4-Impact-Experiment-%F0%9F%A7%AA?type=whiteboard&node-id=0-1&t=9uOFgusAZrL5l5zx-0)
- [Blog post by Open Source Observer](https://docs.opensource.observer/blog/impact-metrics-rf4)
</overview>

<reaction>
- Progress updates: small fixes completed, improvements to the trusted user model.
- UI testing: bugs being fixed, testing rescheduled to June 10th.
- Feedback on voting interface: suggestions for improvements, issues with comment sorting, and ballot management.
- Concerns about gas and transaction count metrics: potential negative impact on public goods and gas-optimized contracts.
</reaction>

<tldr>
The thread announces Retro Funding 4, focusing on a new metrics-based evaluation approach. It includes survey findings, workshop insights, and next steps for testing and refining metrics. Community feedback highlights progress updates, UI testing, and concerns about specific metrics.
</tldr>
